The Consumer Rights Act 2015 will make it far easier for groups of consumers to seek compensation from firms that have fixed prices and formed anti-competitive agreements to fix prices.

Competition law means that agreements between companies not to undercut one another or to fix the prices that they charge to customers are not allowed. The Competition & Markets Authority (CMA) is responsible for upholding these laws and taking action where this kind of anti-competitive agreement is discovered.

But the CMA cannot always make legal decisions about every single consumer with a claim so it can use the CMA Collective Proceeding Rules 2015 to allow claimants to take group action in court. This applies to claims brought in the High Court or the Court of Session in Scotland.

The new regime for group action allows large numbers of people who are suffering from an anti-competitive agreement or who have been wrongly charged prices that are higher than they should have been for a period of time to raise a legal claim.
